How does my life affect my physical and mental health?

I certainly believe that our state of mind and body at any point in time is strongly dictated by our state of mind and body in the hours and days prior to that. And on the one hand, people are going to hear that and say, “Well duh, if you’re sleep-deprived, you’re going to feel like garbage. And if you’re well-rested, you’ll feel great.” That’s kind of the top contour of it. But when one looks at the neuroscience, for instance, of sleep, you start to realize that the amount of rapid eye movement sleep that you’re going to get in any 90-minute bout of sleep, because your sleep is broken up into these 90-minute segments, more or less, is strongly dictated by the ratio of slow wave sleep, AKA deep sleep and rapid eye movement sleep that you had in the previous 90-minute bout.

How does focus work?

When you start to look at the research in terms of waking states, you start to find that your ability to be focused, say, for a bout of work in the morning or the afternoon, or a creative brainstorm session, or I don’t know, to maybe drill into some personal issue that you’re dealing with during therapy or just on a walk or while journaling is not a square wave function. None of us should sit down and expect ourselves to just drop into that state. Much of our ability to move into that state effectively, whatever effective means, whatever the target or goal of that bout as I’m calling it, is going to be dictated by what happened in the previous moments and hours. And so when I zoom out from that, what I’ve doubled down on in this is this idea that there are just a core set of foundational things that we have to re-up every 24 hours.

What happens if I don’t sleep enough

In the absence of quality sleep over two or three days, you’re just going to fall to pieces. In the presence of quality-sufficient sleep over two or three days, you’re going to function at an amazing level. There’s a gain of function and a loss of function there. It’s not just if you sleep poorly, you function less well. You sleep better, you function much better. So sleep, I would say, is at the top of the list. I think thanks to the incredibly hard work of Dr. Matt Walker at Berkeley, The Sleep Diplomat on Twitter, it’s such a great name because it’s so appropriate. A decade ago or so, it was like, “I’ll sleep when I’m dead.” That was the dominant mentality out there. And yeah, sleep’s great, but getting stuff done is more important. Matt has really impressed on everybody that our mental health, our physical health, and our ability to perform is so strongly dependent on our ability to get quality sleep — maybe not every night of our life; we have to be realistic — but that sleep is vital. So a hat tip is insufficient. So sleep is critical, but sleep is just one of about, I would say five things that really set the buoyancy or the foundation upon which our nervous system is able to accomplish these transitions that I’m talking about at all.

Why Neuroplasticity Is the Key To Learning?

The mental strain you feel when you’re learning something is the trigger for neuroplasticity for your brain to change. Neuroplasticity is a process of taking something where there’s a duration path and outcome — where I’m working hard. I’m thinking hard. Maybe it’s a hard conversation. Maybe it’s a business plan. Maybe it’s a scientific career. And the goal of neuroplasticity is to make things reflexive. So you don’t have to think about them. Neuroplasticity … has two parts. One is the trigger … In adults it is triggered by focus and attention and even a heightened state of agitation. The more frustrated you feel, the more you’re actually triggering learning and saying, ‘this is important.’ The second part is deep relaxation … that’s when the connections between neurons called synapses actually get stronger. That’s when the connections that you don’t want get removed.

Do you believe in the science of gratitude, considering its proven ability to enhance happiness and foster a success mindset?

I used to think that gratitude was synonymous with complacency, and I feared that embracing it might undermine my persistence. But then I discovered the fascinating interplay between serotonin and dopamine—serotonin resets dopamine, empowering you to re-enter the fray with renewed vigor and endurance. It's intriguing to note that even in the intense world of high-risk special operations, where the stakes are sky-high, high-performers swear by gratitude practices. I find it personally inspiring to see how they seamlessly incorporate gratitude into their routines.I think a deliberate practice of relishing or enjoying what we have is so powerful and not just going through the motions, if we’re not enjoying it and we’re just waiting for the end result, we’re going to be unhappy.

How do binding behaviors play a role in the process of addiction recovery and the regulation of associated actions?

Binding behaviors involve people structuring their actions around a specific substance or behavioral addiction, such as sex or video games, in both space and time. This means engaging in these behaviors only in specific places and times, aligning with context appropriateness. Examples abound, showcasing how individuals regulate the occurrence of dopamine-releasing behaviors. When individuals opt for cold turkey or employ binding behaviors, they activate specific circuits in the prefrontal cortex, training it to contextualize and regulate actions related to substances like food, sex, or video games.

What neurochemical is released by the neurons in the sympathetic chain ganglia when activated during the acute stress response?
The acute stress response, also known as short-term stress, involves a collection of neurons known as the sympathetic chain ganglia. Despite its name,

in this context means together, and this group of neurons extends from the neck down to approximately the navel, or slightly lower. It's crucial to understand that within the core of our body, there exists a chain of neurons that swiftly activates when we encounter stressors—whether they originate in our thoughts or emerge from our environment. For instance, this activation might occur when facing fears such as heights or encountering someone we strongly dislike. Picture this chain of neurons as a series of dominoes falling in rapid succession. When triggered, these neurons release a neurochemical called acetylcholine at various sites within the body. This process is remarkably fast and occurs in response to both mental and environmental stressors.

What is the Fastlane to calm?

The physiological sigh is a fascinating aspect of our diaphragm, a skeletal muscle that sets it apart from other internal organs. Unlike the spleen, heart, or pancreas, we can voluntarily control our diaphragm. This unique ability allows us to intentionally regulate our breath, a process facilitated by the phrenic nerve. Whether we're about to sleep, recovering from crying or facing claustrophobia, the diaphragm is under our conscious command, offering a direct pathway from the brain to this crucial respiratory muscle.

What is the crucial consideration when it comes to the use of breathing?

Many people worry that their heart rate does not come down fast enough. There's actually something called the vasovagal response, where people will stand up or get up in the middle of the night to use the bathroom, and then all of a sudden, they'll collapse, they'll faint. That's because the heart rate was reduced too much. Some people will see blood or something really troubling and stressful, and they'll pass out. That's an over-activation or an acceleration of the calming response. They're not so stressed that they kind of fall off the cliff of stress. They get so stressed that the rebound mechanism for calming themselves down goes too high, too fast. They calm down too fast and they collapse and faint. So, be aware that if you're going to use the physiological sigh or exhale-emphasized breathing to calm down, that your heart rate will take about 20 to 30 seconds to come down to baseline. And you may need to repeat the physiological sigh a few times

What is the difference between habits and reflexes?

Many people believe that habits are akin to reflexes, but pure reflexes are more like the eye blink reflex. Something approaches your eye, and you blink. Step on a sharp object or encounter intense heat, and you instinctively move away. These are hard-wired reflexes. Habits, on the other hand, are learned by our nervous system, often not consciously. Some habits go unnoticed until they pose an issue or prove beneficial. Habits are a significant part of our identity, constituting a large portion of our actions—up to 70% of our waking behavior, in fact.

what is a linchpin habit?

Linchpin habits are enjoyable activities that make executing other habits easier. Personally, I like cardiovascular exercise, specifically running, and resistance training 3 to 4 times a week for 30-60 minutes. Doing these activities early in the day enhances the associated neurochemistry and hormones. These habits, which I call linchpin habits, are easy to execute and facilitate other habits.

For those 65 and older, a dual approach blending physical and mental training—proves more effective than relying on physical training alone. For most, the scales tip in favor of physical training, but the sweet spot lies in a harmonious marriage of both physical and mental exercises. How does the process of addiction recovery differ for severe cases compared to other addictions?

Recovery from addiction often requires a 30-day period of total abstinence, involving discomfort, cravings, anxiety, and insomnia due to a dopamine trough. Severe cases may need specialized guidance or tapering-off. For addictions like food, sex, or video games, the goal is setting boundaries for a balanced life, not necessarily complete elimination.

How does conscious control of breathing influence stress, alertness, and overall mental and physical performance?

Breathing is essential to life and is unique in that it lies at the interface between conscious and subconscious behavior. We can consciously take control of how we breathe at any moment. By changing our pattern of breathing, we can quickly change what our brain is capable of doing. Breathing can be used to reduce stress, become more alert, and improve physical and cognitive performance. We can control our mental health, physical health, and performance by controlling our breathing.

Can taking melatonin supplements be helpful as a sleep aid?

I find it effective to shift my circadian clock, but I'm not a fan of exogenous melatonin. Many supplements contain excessive doses, and reliability issues abound brands may misrepresent dosages. I advocate for behavioral tools first: morning sunlight, limited nighttime light, and mindful nutrition. Hunger or late-night eating hinder sleep. Quality exercise and avoiding caffeine post-3 PM matter. Before considering supplements or prescriptions, prioritize these zero-cost lifestyle factors.

How can I help my anxiety?

For everyday anxiety, not a full-blown disorder (which requires professional help), there are real-time tools to manage stress. Collaborating with our psychiatry associate chair, David Spiegel, we're exploring a study on the physiological sigh—a breathing pattern from sleep that reduces anxiety effectively when awake. This sigh involves a deep inhale through the nose, sneaking in a bit more air when the lungs feel full, followed by a slow exhale through the mouth. It mirrors a natural sleep response to high carbon dioxide levels, offering a practical way to raise our stress threshold.

How do you build mental resilience?

To cope better with stress, the goal is to embrace and control adrenaline spikes. Familiarize yourself with that heart-racing feeling, like before a presentation or a tough conversation. Instead of letting external factors stress you out, intentionally induce a controlled state of stress. One way is through a cold shower—stay calm amid the adrenaline rush. Another technique is cyclic hyperventilation: breathe rapidly in through the nose and out through the mouth, gradually increasing the intensity. For anxiety, start slow, perhaps with five breaths, and gradually build resilience by pushing your adrenaline threshold over time. Remember, it's not about avoiding adrenaline; it's about navigating it effectively.

What is the power of cognition in health?

I always advocate for changing behaviors, but imagine if we could enhance our well-being simply with our minds. Well, we can, through a technique my lab developed called non-sleep deep rest (NSDR). By inducing deep relaxation in the nervous system, NSDR has proven benefits: replenishing dopamine levels for motivation, enhancing cognitive function, and even compensating for missed sleep. It's a mental tool for better healing and dealing with both psychological and physical challenges. Try it in the morning if you're short on sleep
